title: The Strength of Fellowship
devotional:
Old Man Hemlock sat on the porch, whittling away at a piece of cedar. The August sun beat down, shimmering off the fields of golden wheat that stretched as far as the eye could see. A younger man, Thomas, approached, his brow furrowed with concern. "Mr. Hemlock," he began, "the harvest is nearly upon us, and half the town refuses to speak to the other half. The feud between the families of the east and west sides has reached a fever pitch. How are we supposed to work together to bring in the crops?" Mr. Hemlock sighed, the sound like the rustling of dry leaves. He set down his knife and looked at Thomas, his eyes filled with a lifetime of wisdom. "Thomas, have you ever watched a flock of birds in flight? They aren't all the same color, nor do they all sing the same song. Some are strong fliers, others are weak. Yet, they move together, sharing the air and lifting each other on the currents. If one bird breaks away, the whole flock suffers."

Thomas pondered this. "But Mr. Hemlock, these families have deep-seated grievances. Accusations of theft, slander, and even violence have been thrown around for years." Mr. Hemlock nodded. "Yes, wounds fester when they are left untended. But what heals a wound, Thomas? Is it isolation, or is it the careful tending and cleansing by another? These families are members of one body. Each one benefits from the other’s well-being. If one part suffers, the whole suffers. The feud is affecting the whole town, and this harvest season is no exception."

Fellowship, Thomas, is not about agreeing on every point or forgetting past hurts. It’s about recognizing our shared humanity, our shared need, and our shared purpose. It’s about choosing to work together, even when it’s difficult, because we understand that we are stronger together than we are apart. The church itself is a diverse body, many parts with different functions. A disagreement amongst the parts will halt a church, organization, or even a society.
image_description: A weathered porch with a rocking chair and a half-finished piece of wood carving of birds resting on the chair.
insights: The concept of fellowship as a vital component of the Christian life is deeply rooted in Scripture. Acts 2:42 describes the early church as being devoted to 'the apostles’ teaching and to fellowship, to the breaking of bread and to prayer.' This passage highlights the importance of shared learning, shared meals, and shared prayer in building a strong community of believers. Furthermore, 1 Corinthians 12:12-27 uses the analogy of the human body to illustrate the interconnectedness of Christians, emphasizing that each member is essential and that all suffer when one suffers.
prayer: Heavenly Father, we confess that we often struggle to live in true fellowship with one another. Forgive us for the times when we allow pride, resentment, and division to separate us. Help us to see each other as members of one body, united by Your love and purpose. Grant us the grace to forgive those who have wronged us, to listen with empathy, and to work together for the common good. May Your Spirit empower us to build bridges of understanding and reconciliation, so that we may reflect Your love to the world. In Jesus' name, Amen.
reflection: In what areas of your life do you struggle to experience genuine fellowship? What steps can you take to build stronger relationships with those around you, especially those who are different from you? How can you actively promote unity and reconciliation in your community?
